channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Many of Hurricane Ian’s Victims Were Older Adults Who Drowned
item.description: The storm, Florida’s deadliest since 1935, has been linked to the deaths of at least 119 people in the state, many of them older residents who lived near the coast.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith, Frances Robles, Eliza Fawcett and Ava Sasani
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Search-and-rescue workers combed Fort Myers Beach, Fla., last week after Hurricane Ian’s destructive landfall.

item.title: White House Tightens Rules on Counterterrorism Drone Strikes
item.description: A classified new policy requires President Biden’s approval to add suspected terrorists to a kill list. The Trump administration had decentralized control over targeting decisions.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: John Moore/Getty Images
item.media:description: An Air Force Predator drone, right, returning from a mission in the Persian Gulf region in 2016. The new policy suggests that the United States intends to launch fewer drone strikes away from recognized war zones.

item.title: U.S. Job Growth Eases, but Is Too Strong to Suit Investors
item.description: The gain of 263,000 was shy of recent monthly totals but still robust. Stocks fell on fears of a harder, longer Fed campaign to fight inflation.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember

item.title: Stocks Tumble as Jobs Report Leaves Investors Bracing for a Big Rate Increase
item.description: Fresh data showing continued strength in the labor market solidified investors’ expectations that the Federal Reserve will need to keep acting aggressively to cool the economy.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and Isabella Simonetti

item.title: The Job Market Has Been Like Musical Chairs. Will the Music Stop?
item.description: Many workers grew comfortable thinking they had plenty of options. Now “everybody’s feeling the whiplash,” and anxiety is rising.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: As Debbie Ricks pursued her dream career as a photojournalist, the restaurant jobs that she thought would be a safety net started disappearing.

item.title: Biden Administration Clamps Down on China’s Access to Chip Technology
item.description: The White House issued sweeping restrictions on selling semiconductors and chip-making equipment to China, an attempt to curb the country’s access to critical technologies.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A semiconductor factory in Nantong, China. New limits on sales of semiconductor technology aim to slow the progress of Chinese military programs.

item.title: Groups Plan Voter Outreach for Montana Tribes After Court Lifts Restrictions
item.description: The voting laws had eliminated same-day registration, banned paid third-party ballot collection and made it harder to vote with a student ID.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Louise Johns for The Washington Post via Getty Images
item.media:description: Many voters in Montana, especially Native Americans living on rural reservations, rely on third-party ballot collection to return their absentee ballots.

item.title: How a Dog’s Killing Turned Brooklyn Progressives Against One Another
item.description: After a sudden confrontation that left a golden retriever dead, neighbors came together online to support the owner of the dog. But then things changed.
item.dc:creator: John Leland
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times

item.title: ‘They Are in a Panic’: Ukraine’s Troops Size Up the Enemy
item.description: Ukrainian soldiers are exulting in their smashing of Russian lines in the northeast. They engaged enemy troops up close, and gained confidence from it.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Winners Share a Past Shadowed by Russian Abuses
item.description: Democracy advocates from Belarus, Russia and Ukraine were jointly awarded the world’s most prestigious peace prize, an implicit condemnation of the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine and repression at home.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Megan Specia and Andrew Higgins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Freitas/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A picture of the jailed Belarus rights activist Ales Bialiatski, one of this year’s Nobel Peace Prize winners, is placed next to previous laureates in the garden of the Nobel Institute in Oslo, Norway.

item.title: Columbia University to Pay $165 Million to Victims of Former Doctor
item.description: Robert A. Hadden, a gynecologist, pleaded guilty in 2016 to abusing 19 women, but got no prison time. He is currently facing federal charges.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert A. Hadden is accused by prosecutors of luring women across state lines to his Manhattan office to engage in illegal sex acts.

item.title: A Vermeer? It’s Actually an Imitator, National Gallery of Art Reveals.
item.description: Museum researchers said there was enough evidence to warrant changing the attribution of one of its four Vermeers.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: Sideline Doctors Face Scrutiny After Hits to a Star Quarterback
item.description: Physicians assessing head injuries at N.F.L. games are expected to be able to diagnose concussions. But recent injuries to Tua Tagovailoa raised questions about how effective the doctors can be.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson, Jenny Vrentas and Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Rebecca Blackwell/Associated Press
item.media:description: Miami Dolphins quarterback Tua Tagovailoa was helped off the field after he hit his head on the turf in a Sept. 25 game against Buffalo. He was examined and allowed to return.

item.title: Is a ‘Soft Launch’ Right for Your Relationship?
item.description: A term used by businesses to slowly roll out products has been adopted by couples who want to avoid putting their relationship under the microscope of social media.
item.dc:creator: Laura Pitcher
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: For some couples who want to avoid judgment on social media, the soft launch, similar to a company slowly revealing a new product, has become a popular way to discreetly share a new relationship.

item.title: A Lost Manuscript Shows the Fire Barack Obama Couldn’t Reveal on the Campaign Trail
item.description: At Harvard Law, he wrote a blistering manifesto he never published. Its searing advice could help Democrats escape their current political quagmire.
item.dc:creator: Timothy Shenk
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Democrats Can’t Afford to Lose Nevada
item.description: A loss in the race for Senate could change the direction of the country on major public policy issues.
item.dc:creator: Jon Ralston
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times

item.title: Putin and M.B.S. Are Laughing at Us
item.description: Putin’s motivation for OPEC’s price hike is no mystery.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Kevin Lamarque/Reuters

item.title: We Had to Force the Constitution to Accommodate Democracy, and It Shows
item.description: We tend to equate American democracy with the Constitution, but our history makes it clear that the two are in tension with each other.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: The N.Y.U. Chemistry Students Shouldn’t Have Needed That Petition
item.description: High-stakes weed-out classes like organic chemistry are relics of an age when college students were much more uniformly privileged.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Calarco
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times

item.title: A Language Test That Stigmatizes Black Children
item.description: Black English is not slang. It is a dialect with clear rules and structure.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter
item.media:credit: Delcan and Co.

item.title: ‘It’s Like a War Out There.’ Iran’s Women Haven’t Been This Angry in a Generation.
item.description: The gap between the freedoms and opportunities enjoyed by the system’s affiliated elite and those of ordinary Iranians has never been so wide.
item.dc:creator: Azadeh Moaveni
item.media:credit: Richard Tomkins/Associated Press
item.media:description: Iranian women demonstrating for equal rights in 1979.

item.title: In the Battle With Robots, Human Workers Are Winning
item.description: Technologists have long been warning that robots will replace human workers. It doesn’t seem to be happening.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo

item.title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Cheung and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Hangover Anxiety: How a Night of Drinking Can Tank Your Mood
item.description: Consuming alcohol can mess with your emotions the next day by causing stress hormones to spike and sleep to be disrupted overnight.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Pablo Delcan

item.title: How to Learn My Love Language
item.description: A Deaf man has been let down by every lover he’s ever had. This time might be different.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Winter Squash Every Which Way
item.description: As well as a how-to for making your own pumpkin spice blend.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Nik Sharma for The New York Times (Photography and Styling)

item.title: Ohio Judge Indefinitely Suspends State’s Abortion Ban
item.description: The court extended its suspension of the six-week ban while the legal battle proceeds.
item.dc:creator: Ava Sasani
item.media:credit: Barbara J. Perenic/The Columbus Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters rallied in support of abortion rights at the Ohio Statehouse in Columbus in June.

item.title: Uvalde Suspends Its Entire School Police Force
item.description: The move follows a protest from families over the police response to a May 24 mass shooting that killed 19 students and two teachers.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives of victims of the mass shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, including Gloria Cazares, center, were overcome with emotion after learning of the suspension of school district police officers on Friday.

item.title: Mayor Adams Declares State of Emergency in NYC Over Migrant Crisis
item.description: Mayor Eric Adams stepped up calls for state and federal aid as the number of people in city shelters topped 61,000.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: New people arrived at a homeless shelter intake center in Brooklyn on Thursday, many carrying bags from a Texas social services agency.

item.title: After Day Care Massacre, Thailand Is Roiled With Grief
item.description: Anguished families were coming to terms with the loss of their young children as the nation pondered issues like gun violence and the widespread availability of deadly weapons.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee, Ryn Jirenuwat and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Andre Malerba for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners pray at the gates of the day care center at the Uthai Sawan subdistrict office on Friday in Nong Bua Lamphu, Thailand.

item.title: For Some Breast Cancer Survivors, October Is the Cruelest Month
item.description: Pink ribbons can be a tough reminder for many breast cancer survivors. Here’s how to make it easier.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Breast cancer is 365 days a year, not 31,” said Bri Majsiak, who co-founded a nonprofit organization for people impacted by breast and gynecological cancers.

item.title: Burnout vs Depression: How to Tell the Difference and Find Relief
item.description: Clinicians and researchers offer advice on how to tell the difference, and what to do about both.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Pharmacies Are Entering the Mental Health Market
item.description: Call it the ultimate in “retail therapy.” Now you can shop for mental health services at CVS, Rite Aid and other national chains.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: A CVS health clinic in Spring, Texas. The pharmacy chain has started including mental health services in some of its stores.

item.title: The Push to Landmark the Last-Known ‘Colored’ School in Manhattan
item.description: The historic building at 128 West 17th Street has been vacant for years, and preservation advocates fear its damaged roof may eventually prompt developers to tear it down.
item.dc:creator: John Freeman Gill
item.media:credit: Right: Clark Hodgin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The vacant, city-owned building at 128 West 17th Street in Chelsea, shown at left in a circa-1939 tax photo and at right today, is a rare relic of the city’s racially segregated 19th-century school system. For 34 years, it housed one of a handful of “colored” schools in Manhattan.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
